captions.content: I was talking about Chicago.

people say, you know, the walk

Think you're better than me. Hate that s**t.

they'd come back with another dog.

Eight of those dogs were my dogs'. Dogs.
Um, I try to tell that to Jennifer.
She ain't even listening, you know?
Uh, I'm Sam Miller from Olympia Washington.
Greatest town in the world.
All right. So you say it's the greatest town in the world.
Is that just fluffy, I mean, really?
Mm-Hmm. No, I've been everywhere man.
And I keep coming back to Olympia
'cause that's where my wife is.
Yeah. And my kids. That makes sense. Yeah. Yeah, yeah.
I just love it. 'cause in Olympia I have one of everything.
You know I have a barber, I have a mechanic,
like all these beautiful people.
I hang out with a lot of musicians. I hang out with a lot.
I hang out with some poets, some painters
and a couple comedians.
Uh, and I'm very lucky.
Tell me about your first album. What's
This? Oh, first album,
first album's called Round Trip.
Recorded it at the Capitol Theater in um, April of 2023.
So recorded it almost a year ago now.
Um, or more than,
I don't even know, maybe it was more than a year.
I can't tell. I don't know how time works.
There's been a few moments in my life
where I've had real clarity
and one of those moments was watching Cops in jail
and giving these guys advice on TV
and realizing that I am in no place
to be given this man advice,
Considering my current predicament there.
And dude, man, yeah, I'm really proud of it.
It was funny, I was just hanging out with Dan, um,
the CEO deep guy and uh, we've become really good friends
and he was talking about some other comic
who says they hate their first album.
And I asked him if I was like,
do you think I'm gonna hate my first album?
And he goes, maybe someday.
But, um, I don't know if I'm gonna get that or not
because I'm really proud of that album.
I think it's pretty good. So I like, it's got a good arc
to it and it's got good jokes
and it's got solid laughs throughout
and I think I make some decent points here
or there without trying to, you know. Yeah.
And tell me about, you know, I mean since it was your
first album, you had your whole lifetime to write it.
What parts of your life definitely pop out of
The album? I mean, you're gonna
hear a lot, uh, homelessness,
incarceration, um, that's what I like to write about.
My, one of my favorite people in the world.
This dude named Gabe Rutledge, great comedian, you know,
he is also an Olympia, he told me a long time ago.
He is like, the best way to do standup is to talk about
what makes you laugh and then just
invite other people along.
And like, that's the s**t that me and my friends joke about.
We joke about crazy s**t. We joke about being locked up.
We joke about living outside
'cause it, that's the only way I could survive that.
And that's how I survived that.
Fans are also people that have been through a lot
of hard s**t and I don't, and I, I love them man.
It's, it's awesome. I get cool
messages from people all the time.
Standup doesn't have a monopoly on humor.

and I'd be funny if I stopped doing standup

Touch a moment on how social media has affected

Well,
people can think whatever they want about social

I love this question 'cause it's interesting to me.
'cause I used to not like it. I was like,
I'll just be really funny and then somebody else will figure
that part out for me.
But that's just not the way the industry is anymore.
Like basically nobody's coming for anybody.
And uh, it's not about how funny you are.
It's, it's, it's how well how many people.
You can show how funny you are too.
And it's, people could be like, oh, that's, that's weird.
But I mean there used to be a lot of kiss asses
that would work comedy clubs
and probably get spots they didn't deserve.
'cause it used to be the comedy clubs put you in front
of the people, but now it's more like the people put you in
front of the comedy clubs, you know?
And I try to just stay genuine. That's what it is, man.
Honestly, it's just like on stage.
It's like the minute you start doing an
impression of yourself, you're f****d.
I see comics do that all the time and I see it online.
I see it in person where they're like, this is
what it would be like if I did standup comedy as opposed
to just coming up on stage and being funny.
I didn't, this wasn't like a plan.
Other people told me I should try it.
And now like in a lot of ways, like I love my life.
I'm like 53% happy. I used to only be about 51.
Now I'm probably like 53% happy. That's great.
And that's pretty good for a guy like me know.

to get into comedy ever ring you up
and go, I would like a piece of that
Now? No, they
can kick rocks.
